did.unittitle: Helen Hornbeck Tanner papers 1930s-2009
did.abstract: Historian of American Indian history and literature, research associate at the Newberry Library, secretary of the Michigan Commission on Indian Affairs, and expert witness in legal cases involving Indian treaty rights. The collection contains correspondence, reports, clippings, and printed material concerning work of the Commission and status of Indians in Michigan; also depositions and other documents in the case of United States v. Michigan, landmark Indian fishing rights case.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Helen Hornbeck Tanner (donor no. 4308) and came to the library in multiple accessions. The last accession came from the Tanner estate through Helen Tannerâ€™s daughters.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Donor transferred her copyright to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Helen Hornbeck Tanner papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Helen Hornbeck Tanner was a distinguished scholar of American Indian history and literature, publishing books on the Caddo and the Ojibwa as well as on early eighteenth-century Spanish Florida.

A native of Minnesota, born July 5, 1916, Helen Hornbeck Tanner grew up mainly in Kalamazoo, Michigan. She was educated at Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania (1937); University of Florida, Gainesville (1948); and the University of Michigan, where she received a doctoral degree in 1961. She taught courses in Latin American history, and later in American Indian history for the University of Michigan Extension Service and occasionally at the U-M Ann Arbor campus.

Beginning in 1963, she began a career as an expert witness in cases heard by the Indian Claims Commission in Washington D.C. Probably her most significant single case was United States v. Michigan, which established Native American fishing rights in the Great Lakes based on 19th-century treaties. Tanner was the lead witness for the plaintiffs and summarized the evidence of early and continuing Native American fishing on the lakes. From 1966 to 1970 she was a member of the Michigan Commission on Indian Affairs.

Her Bibliography of the Ojibwa (1974) was one of the early publications of the Center for American Indian History at The Newberry Library. She also prepared maps of Indian locations for the Atlas of Early American History (1976), and consulted for the Smith Center for the History of Cartography in 1974. In 1976, she joined the Newberry staff as director of the project that produced the Atlas of Great Lakes Indian History (1987). She remained as a Research Associate, and in 1996 she became a Senior Research Fellow.

scopecontent.p: The Helen Hornbeck Tanner papers are composed of ten series: Personal / Biographical; Correspondence; Articles and other writings; Research and Writing Projects; Conferences and symposia; Topical files; Michigan Commission on Indian Affairs; U.S. v. Michigan; Other Litigation; and Printed Material.

did.unittitle: Personal / Biographical

scopecontent.p: The Personal / Biographical series is of most value for the transcripts of oral history interviews that Tanner gave to researchers about her life and career activities.

Correspondence

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series dates from the 1930s to 2009. The letters are from students, colleagues and other historians, publishers, Native American activists and community leaders, and from attorneys and others involved in litigation involving Indian rights. The researcher should note that there is correspondence throughout the collection.

did.unittitle: 2002 Christmas

scopecontent.p: The Articles and other writings series contains drafts of articles, reprints, books reviews written by her, and reviews of her own work.

scopecontent.p: The Research and Writing Projects series documents both proposed and completed research and writing endeavors. Much of this concerns her highly praised Atlas of Great Lakes Indian History.

Topical files

scopecontent.p: The Topical files series, arranged alphabetically, consists of subject correspondence, papers and letters from named individuals, collected materials relating to specific interests and activities, research material. Of interest is her correspondence with, and articles written by Native American writer and personality Keewaydinoquay M. Peschel (called Kee by those who knew her). Kee was an Indian medicine woman, educated at Central Michigan University and Michigan State University in botany and biology. She lived on Garden Island, one of the Beaver Islands in Michigan. Tanner and Tanner corresponded with each other over many years.

Michigan Commission on Indian Affairs

scopecontent.p: Michigan Commission on Indian Affairs: Tanner was a member of the Michigan Commission on Indian Affairs from 1966 to 1970 and secretary of the commission for a portion of that time. This series contains copies of correspondence and other documents relating to the commission.

Printed material
U.S. v. Michigan (case of Indian claims against the state of Michigan on matters of fishing rights)

scopecontent.p: U.S. v. Michigan: This case, argued in Grand Rapids, Mich., before U.S. District Judge Noel Fox in 1978 and 1979, led to a landmark decision affirming Native Americans' right to fish in the Great Lakes under 19th-century treaties. The plaintiffs, the United States with the Bay Mills Indian Community and Sault Ste. Marie Tribe, were suing the State of Michigan and Michigan Dept. of Natural Resources to enforce Native American fishing rights. Tanner was an expert witness for the plaintiffs in the case, and the collection contains depositions, testimony, briefs, and other documents from the case. Also included is a file of notes Tanner received from the Native American Rights Fund summarizing and commenting on a number of the depositions and other documents.

Other Litigation

scopecontent.p: The Other Litigation series documents Tanner's historical research and contribution as expert witness to such cases as United States and Saginaw Chippewa Tribe v. Michigan (1992) and the Turtle River Casino gambling case, Grand Traverse Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians v. United States Attorney for the Western District of Michigan and the State of Michigan.

Printed material

scopecontent.p: The Printed material series includes professional archaeological journals, periodical journals specializing in Native American history, and various newspapers and newsletters.

did.unittitle: Professional archaeological journals, periodical journals specializing in Native American history, etc.; include issues of Caddoan Archaeology, and Le Journal among other publications

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Bentley Historical Library holds a collection of maps donated by Tanner, relating to her work as an expert witness in cases before the Indian Claims Commission. This collection is part of the library's map collection (M 4112 .L7E1 1810 T3) and is fully described in MIRLYN, the U-M online catalog.

The Newberry Library holds a collection of Tanner's papers. The collection included personal and professional correspondence, research notes, research notebooks, card files, Potawatomi (1997) and Caddo court case materials, and research files and data for maps in Settling of North America (1995).
